title: 113_hr5078
content: The Act may be cited as the "Waters of the United States Regulatory Overreach Protection Act of 2014". It pertains to rules and guidance. The Act prohibits the Secretary and the Administrator from developing, finalizing, adopting, implementing, applying, administering, or enforcing certain proposed rules and guidance related to the definition of 'Waters of the United States' under the Clean Water Act. The Act prohibits the use of proposed rules and guidance related to the definition of 'Waters of the United States' under the Clean Water Act for rulemaking or decision-making. The Act prohibits using proposed rules or guidance for decision-making under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. Additionally, certain agricultural conservation practices are exempt from specific permitting requirements. The Secretary and the Administrator will withdraw the interpretive rule exempting certain agricultural conservation practices from permitting requirements under the Clean Water Act. This rule will have no force or effect, and Section 404(f)(1)(A) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act will be applied without regard to the interpretive rule. The federalism consultation is addressed in Section 3. The Secretary and the Administrator will consult with State and local officials to develop recommendations for a regulatory proposal on the scope of waters covered under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. They will also seek input from a diverse group of officials representing various perspectives in the United States. The consultation process with State and local officials regarding the scope of waters covered under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act should emphasize collaboration, timely input, respect for the Federal-State partnership, consideration of differences in geography and priorities, transparency, and exploration of alternative means to achieve Federal objectives. The Secretary and the Administrator must publish a draft report in the Federal Register within 12 months of the Act's enactment, detailing recommendations developed under subsection (a). Consensus among all parties is required for a recommendation to be included in the report, and failure to reach consensus on a regulatory proposal must be identified in the draft report. The draft report must identify areas of consensus and disagreement, along with reasons for disagreements. There will be a 180-day public review period, and a final report will be prepared in consultation with State and local officials. The final report must be submitted to Congress within 24 months. The final report prepared under subsection (c)(5) must be submitted to Congress within 24 months of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as Secretary, Administrator, and State and local officials. The House of Representatives passed this Act on September 9, 2014.
